stem: The nurse is preparing a single syringe containing both Regular and NPH insulin. Place the steps in the correct order.

rows.text: Inject air into the NPH (Cloudy) insulin vial.
Inject air into the Regular (Clear) insulin vial.

rationale.correct: The 'Clear before Cloudy' rule prevents contamination of the fast-acting insulin. (1) Air in Cloudy. (2) Air in Clear. (3) Draw up Clear (Regular). (4) Draw up Cloudy (NPH). This sequence ensures that any residual NPH in the needle doesn't get pushed into the Regular vial.
rationale.incorrect: Drawing up NPH before Regular is incorrect because it can alter the peak and onset of the regular insulin if contamination occurs.
clinicalPearls: NPH insulin should be rolled (not shaken) before withdrawal to disperse the particles.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that you inject air into both vials first. The order of air injection is the *reverse* of the drawing-up order. (Air into Cloudy → Air into Clear → Draw Clear → Draw Cloudy).

mnemonic.title: R-N-R-N
mnemonic.expansion: Regular-NPH (Air), Regular-NPH (Draw). Wait, no—'RN' (Registered Nurse) = Regular then NPH for drawing.

reviewUnits.heading: Insulin Administration Safety
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must verify the doses with a second licensed nurse. Long-acting insulins (like Glargine) should never be mixed with other insulins.
